captions.text:
I must go back to Asgard but I give
you my word...
I think I may not want to leave now.
Well I've got my hammer back, I've got a hot girlfriend..

Things are really looking fairly well
for me
Good luck to you old friends!

What can I say? Chicks are my
kryptonite.
Yeah I probably leave it all behind too.

What about your brother? I mean won't he
destroy that ice realm?

Mehh.. if he does I'm sure my father will take
care of it when he wakes.
I destroyed all of Yodenheim while you were sleeping.
And that is why you are also banished!
I take from you, your power!
Your dad is sort of extreme.

Well I suppose he's a little strict but
everything he does, he does
And then raising that baby as your brother..
And making him believe he could be king.
So that he goes crazy with jealousy and becomes your lifelong enemy..
Yes well, that may be true.
But at least I have a father.

So are just gonna do this every time a
super hero comes along?
I've been carrying this hammer all day and my arms are so Thor!

comments.text:
+Ace Ender After reading your comment, I'm going to assume what you wrote 
is based on Marvel retconning the event I'm about to describe within the 
last 10-15 years ago.

Actually Captain America was fully capable of lifting Mjolnir in the 
comics. At the time, Steve was "The Captain" (Red, white, and black 
costume) and not Captain America. Thor was unsure who to trust between 
Steve and Iron Man. There had been some turmoil in the Avengers previously, 
and Steve didn't seem like the person he remembered.

Thor lost the hammer during a battle and Steve grabbed it while he was 
being piled on by enemies. He suddenly sent all of his attackers flying, 
and found himself in possession of Mjolnir. He remarked at how much power 
he could feel, and didn't feel comfortable with it. He threw Mjolnir back 
to Thor when he located him.

After the battle and seeing that Steve was worthy of wielding Mjolnir, Thor 
realized Steve was still the man he knew, that Tony's trustworthiness was 
questionable, and that he would never question Steve's loyalty and trust 
again.

Now Marvel may have retconned a thing or two in the comics, so that may not 
be how things currently stand in the comics now.
comments.author: MVG

comments.author: Ace Ender

comments.text: it's not based on strength, it's based on whether your thor or not.
comments.author: Shadowlink64Gaming

comments.text:
No, he normally can't. He was able to use it during the Justice 
League/Avengers crossover to fight Krona, but only temporarily. Thor 
basically gave the hammer to Superman because Thor couldn't continue 
fighting and Superman could. Despite Superman being essentially a good 
person, he still isn't worthy of wielding Mjolnir.

Superman couldn't lift the hammer after the battle was over. Now the Golden 
Age Superman could lift the hammer just by sheer strength, regardless of 
how the enchantment works.
